20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

To this day, we still can much of our garden produce and also can our meat for summer use.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Relatives and friends in Ontario sent out barrels of dried apples and apple-butter in the early days. This did much to relieve the monotony of meals.

I also started 8 regular boarders in the early days. However, later on in 1910 or so for one whole summer I served 17 plates three times a day. There were often travellers in those days and they were additional.
21. What did you begin to rely on for canned foods and preserves? (Give as many details as possible.)

To this day, we still can much of our garden produce and also can fruit.

22. Plans and other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and making foods in other than urban places in eastern Canada.

Include items not covered above, such as prices, problems of storage, etc.

If more space is needed, use additional pages.

Relatives and friends in Ontario and our family drank apple and apple-butter in the early days. This did much to relieve the monotony of meals.

I also started regular breakfasts in the early days. However, later on in 1910 or so for the whole summer I served 17 plate three times a day. This was often followed by three days and they were additional.
Big harvest gangs presented an additional problem. Twenty men for two or three weeks were not unusual in those seasons. Their big "Steamer" outfits had their own sleeping quarters (caboose or bunk house).

Meals were plain and hearty. Meat, potatoes, homemade bread & butter, pickles and vegetables, dried fruit and apple butter, dried apple or cream pie. Rhubarb was soon flourishing and added a change.

When we first came west in 1906 all supplies had to be brought from Humboldt, thirty miles from our homestead. Humboldt was our nearest railway until 1907 when the railway was built through [illegible] within 8 miles of our home. The town of Harmony was founded and the railway came into operation the summer of 1908. From then on the problem of supplies and mail was greatly simplified.
Big harvest gangs presented an additional problem. Twenty men for two or three weeks were not unusual in those summers. Many "Steamer" outfits had their own sleeping quarters (cabins or bunk houses). Meals were plain and hearty: meat, potatoes, homemade bread & butter, pickles and vegetables, dried fruit and apple butter, brown apple or cream pie. Flour was very hardworking and dear a charge.

When we first came west in 1906 all supplies had to be brought from Huronwood, thirty miles from our homestead. Huronwood was our nearest railway until 1907 when the railway was built through our town. Our home was founded and the railway came into operation in the summer of 1908. Since then our supplies and mail were greatly simplified.
